abstract.text: Represents the different token types found in a math expression

topicSections.title: Internal token types (used during parsing, but never present in a final `TokenList`)

seeAlsoSections.title: Detailed information about how an expression was interpreted

abstract.text: ;, not colon
3 dp, 3 decimal points
‘1 watermelon = 3 kg’
Two unit expressions back to back, that should be considered as a single token, i.e 10 feet 3 inches
a comment word beginning with #, like #ducks
‘a’, ‘the’ in English, ‘der/die/das’ in German
‘,’, used in the context of natural language, not as a European decimal point
A token that represents a subsheet in a line collection
number, percentage, rate, date, timestamp, timespan, multiplier, fraction etc
like ‘here’
A number formatted in base-16, i.e 0x10F
custom javascript function
A number formatted in base-8, i.e 0o670
A new type defined as part of a custom function definition
A datestamp formatted in iso8601
Something that could potentially have a value one day
’Label: ’
like ‘one’, ‘twenty-three’, ‘million’, ‘billion’
An internal type used in sequence matching to match any string
The index of a token in a
A math error, like the result of 1/0
if (condition) then (action)
An internal type used in sequence matching to match exact string matches
a word or phrase representing a special day in the calendar (“christmas”, “easter”, “chinese new year”, etc)
3-4 letter code, like EST, GMT
“as %, as number, as USD, in days”
Represents some common ‘forms’ a token list might take, and associated data primatives
true or false
An internal type used in date parsing. Should never make it into the final TokenList
a unix timestamp (the number of seconds that have passed since the reference date)
This is a label expression: 123 + 456’ (i.e from the beginning to the first label)
3/day, $3/day, 3%/day
musical pitches using the notation ‘C4’, ‘Bb2’, etc (the final number is the octave)
A unit + a number, i.e 10 minutes or $10
( or ). What americans called parentheses
‘#’ used in tags and headings
‘a’ in ‘a = 2’
a multi-component unit of time, i.e 1 week 2 days 4 hours 3 minutes
A token represents a meaningful element in a math expression (like a number, operator, unit, etc)
A number formatted in base-2, i.e 0b1001
An internal type used in sequence matching to match a string of words that could be resolved into a place via the place provider
a variable declared in the variable list used to parse this expression
10% (VAT, GST, etc) - a special kind of percentage that has different behaviours
A pending thing that could not be resolved
‘// duck’ must have a space after the two slashes to be valid
like ‘total’, ‘count’, ’average
:, not semi-colon
A variable that represents a query outside of SoulverCore, currently only with the form ‘earth mass = ?’
Represents the different token types found in a math expression
Additional metadata about a parsed expression
Something added in post-processing or parsing
k, M, G, etc
Anything in brackets that is evaluatable (123 + 456)
Degrees, Minutes, Seconds (+ optional cardinal direction) type
Contains an array of tokens that represent the various meaningful components of a math expression
A set of token types
a comment word, like ducks in 3 ducks
a = if b == 30 then 10 else 5 OR a = 30 if b == 5 else 10
This token represents an inline declared custom unit
A number that wishes to be expressed as a fraction during formatting
sqrt(123) (optionally with an Object in front)
a multi-compnent unit of time from hours to milliseconds, in the format hh:mm:ss.ms
a multi-compnent unit of time from hours to frames, in the format hh:mm:ss:ff, used for video editing
2x
if, else, then, etc
sqrt, sin, round, etc
1, 2 and 3 - used in some word functions
a suffix applied to number to make it ordinal, 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 5th, etc
as a % of, midpoint between, etc
space… the final frontier
Even more detail captured by the parser about various subtypes that a particular token can be
minute, hour, km, etc
anything in brackets that doesn’t actually include math but would be evaluated ordinarily (123); (duck) is not a bracket comment
‘.’, used in the context of natural language, not as a decimal point
Coordinates of a place (Decimal longitude, decimal latitude)
a word representing a relative point in time like today, yesterday, tuesday, march
Something not yet recognised in parsing
and, or
A coordinate for a token in a
A point in time, i.e January 12 at 4:45 am
‘watermelon’ in ‘1 watermelon = 3 kg’
in, to or as in english
an identifying word that pertains to a date word like ‘last’ in ‘last tuesday’
at the moment ‘from’ and ‘since’, ‘of’ and ‘at’
one point in time to another point in time (like summer)
A powerful natural language calculation engine
Like http://soulver.app
Perform calculations across multiple lines
1, 2, 3, etc - Base 10 decimal numbers
water, milk, gold, beans, etc (relevant for certain weight <-> volume unit conversions)
Inline Soulver 2 comment of style “123”
‘”’ used for quoting things out
A range of a single unit, like 3-4 seconds, 620 to 750 nanometers
